title: AB 1228
content: The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts amendments to the Education Code to encourage dissemination of information to foster care agencies by higher education institutions and explore admissions methods for homeless and foster youth. The State of California encourages California Community Colleges to prioritize housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, providing them with housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. The State of California encourages California Community Colleges to prioritize housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, providing them with housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. Additionally, priority is given to these youth for housing that is available for occupation for the most days in the calendar year. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed, regardless of student housing facilities. A "homeless youth" is defined as a student under 25 years of age who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months by a homeless services provider. A homeless youth, under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months by a homeless services provider, can retain that status for six years from admission. The amendment in the Education Code requests California Community Colleges to ensure housing access for homeless and foster youth, regardless of on-campus housing. Each campus of the California State University must prioritize current and former homeless and foster youth for student housing, providing them with housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. The California State University campuses prioritize current and former homeless and foster youth for student housing, offering housing at no extra cost during academic breaks and giving priority for housing open for occupation most days in the year. Each California State University campus is requested to develop a plan to ensure homeless and foster youth can access housing resources as needed, regardless of student housing availability. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 years old who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months. A homeless services provider, director of federal TRIO or Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs, and a financial aid administrator are included in the amended Education Code section. Former homeless youth retain their status for six years from admission. Each campus of the University of California with student housing facilities must prioritize current and former homeless and foster youth for housing, especially during breaks, providing it at no extra cost. The University of California prioritizes current and former homeless and foster youth for housing during breaks, offering it at no extra cost. Priority is given to these individuals for residence in housing facilities open for most days in the year. The University of California prioritizes housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, ensuring access to housing resources during academic breaks. Homeless youth under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months, are eligible for this support. For a period of six years, certain individuals are eligible for housing support, including a homeless services provider, a director of specific programs, and a financial aid administrator. The University of California is exempt from this provision unless the Regents decide otherwise.
